review.title: Analysis of Spectrum Occupancy Using Machine Learning Algorithms
review.abstract: In this paper, we analyze the spectrum occupancy using different machine learning techniques. Both supervised techniques (naive Bayesian classifier (NBC), decision trees (DT), support vector machine (SVM), linear regression (LR)) and unsupervised algorithm (hidden markov model (HMM)) are studied to find the best technique with the highest classification accuracy (CA). A detailed comparison of the supervised and unsupervised algorithms in terms of the computational time and classification accuracy is performed. The classified occupancy status is further utilized to evaluate the probability of secondary user outage for the future time slots, which can be used by system designers to define spectrum allocation and spectrum sharing policies. Numerical results show that SVM is the best algorithm among all the supervised and unsupervised classifiers. Based on this, we proposed a new SVM algorithm by combining it with fire fly algorithm (FFA), which is shown to outperform all other algorithms.

metadata.title: Analysis of Spectrum Occupancy Using Machine Learning Algorithms

sections.text: In this paper, we analyze the frequency utilization of the spectrum using various machine learning techniques. Both monitored techniques (naive Bayesian classifier (NBC), decision trees (DT), support spectrum (SVM), linear regression (LR), and unattended algorithm (hidden markov model (HMM))) are studied to find the best technique with the highest classification accuracy (CA). A detailed comparison of the monitored and unattended spectrum of algorithms in terms of computation time and classification accuracy is performed. Classified occupancy status is further used to evaluate the likelihood of secondary user failures for the future timeframes that can be used by system designers to define normal frequency allocation and spectrum sharing policies. Numerical results show that SVM is the best algorithm among all monitored and unattended classifiers.

sections.heading: A. Problem definition
sections.text: Many studies have been conducted to understand the occupancy statistics. For example, the statistical and spectral occupancy analysis of the measurements in [2] was presented to study the traffic density in all frequency bands. In [3], the auto-regressive model was used to predict the availability of radio resources using occupancy measurements to achieve uninterrupted data transmission by secondary users. In [4], occupancy statistics were used to select the best channels for control and data transmission purposes, so that less time is needed to switch the transmission from one channel to another in case the PU appears. Furthermore, in [5], [6] bandwidth efficiency was maximized by controlling the transmission performance of cognitive radio using spectrum occupancy measurements. In [7], various time series models were used to categorize specific occupancy patterns in the spectral measurements.

sections.heading: B. Contributions
sections.text: The papers are listed as follows: 1. We propose the use of ML algorithms in the Spectrum Occupancy Study, using both monitored and unmonitored algorithms; the machine learning techniques are advantageous because they are able to implicitly learn the environment and are much more adaptable compared to traditional occupancy models of the spectrum; they can describe more optimized decision regions on trait space than other approaches; in [9] and [10], ML was used for cooperative spectrum scanning; however, we use ML for spectrum occupancy modeling, which can be used in all CR operations, including spectrum management, spectrum decision and spectrum scanning; in [11] the authors discussed call-based modeling to analyze the spectrum usage of the dataset collected by the wireless network operator; and they have shown that the Random Walk modeling process can be used to aggregate the cell.

sections.heading: II. SYSTEM MODEL
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Measurement setup and data
sections.text: We measured the data from 880 MHz to 2500 MHz using radiometers on eight main radio frequency bands for about four months (February 6-June 18, 2013) at the University of Warwick. The eight bands are: 880-915 MHz, 925-960 MHz, 1900-1920 MHz, 1920-1980 MHz, 1710-1785 MHz, 1805-1880 MHz, 2110-2170 MHz and 2400-2500 MHz. The number of frequency bins in each band varies. For example, the band 925-960 MHz contains 192 frequency bins, each taking a bandwidth of 0.18 MHz, while the band 1710-1785 MHz contains 448 frequency bins, each taking a bandwidth of 0.167 MHz. The data is arranged in a two-dimensional matrix (ti, fj) for each band, with each row ti representing the measured data at different frequencies in one minute.

sections.text: In a network of licensed users, SU is allowed to access the licensed band without causing any harmful interference to the PU. sections.heading: D. Machine Learning Framework for SU and PU Model
sections.text: ML constructs a classifier to map Si to P i, where Si = [Si (1), Si (2),.. Si (k)] represents the feature vector and P i is the corresponding response to the feature vector. There are two steps to construct a classifier: 1) Training: Let Sitrain = [S i (1) train, S i (2) train..., S i (k) train] T denote the training spectrum status and P itrain each represent the training PU status for the ith time slot, where i = 1, 2,.. n1 and n1 represent the number of training time slots inserted into the classifier. 2) Testing: Once the classifier is successfully trained, he is ready to receive the test vector for the classification. Let Sitest = [S i (1) test, S i (2) test, iek,... S (itest) i2).

sections.heading: E. Probability of SU outage
sections.text: Let Pieval be a vector of length ((n2 − n1) + 1), which is evaluated by each classifier, and P i eval represent the presence / absence of PU for the ith time slot. If P ieval = 0, SU may use the ith time slot. Define outsu as the minimum value of consecutive free time slots needed by SU for transmission. SU failure occurs when SU does not find consecutive free time slots in a vector pieval of length ((n2 − n1) + 1. The probability of SU failure is given by P (SUoutage) = 1 − P (SUtransmit) (3a), whereas P (SUtransmit) = C ∑ c = 1P (FBc) (3b), where FBc represents the block of free consecutive time slots of length outsu, c = {1, 2.. C} and C stands for the total number of blocks that are available in a starting block, where P = 3val.

sections.heading: III. PROPOSED ALGORITHMS
sections.text: In the proposed approach, five machine learning algorithms are used to predict future PU status based on occupancy data, which is a function of time, frequency and threshold, including four supervised learning algorithms: NBC, DT, SVM and LR, while one is an unattended algorithm, HMM. The motivation to use five different algorithms is to find the best machine learning algorithm because they have different properties.

sections.heading: A. Naive Bayesian Classifier
sections.text: A Naive Bayes Classifier is a generative model based on the Bayes Theorem. It is also referred to as an "independent feature model" because it does not take into account dependence on characteristics. For example, the feature vector for the ith time slot in our model contains all samples that are independent of each other, since each feature represents a specific frequency range. The status vector of the ith time slot is given as Si = Si (1), Si (1), Si (2), Si (k), where Si (1) is independent of Si (2). However, the response variable in our approach, i.e. the PU status (P i), is a dependent variable that is influenced by each frequency range. As our characteristics are independent, we will use NBC for the classification. The probability that Si (1) belongs to class P i is classified as Si class, while Si (Si-class) is classified as Si-class.

sections.heading: B. Decision Trees
sections.text: The decision tree builds classification or regression models in the form of a tree structure. The decision trees used in this approach are classification trees whose leaf represents the class names. Unlike NBC, it can handle interactions and dependencies on characteristics. In DT, the decision is made on each internal node used as the basis for dividing the data into two subsets, while leaf nodes represent the class names (in the case of classification trees) or the real numbers (in the case of regression trees). The data comes in the form of 25 March 2015 DRAFT9 (Si, P i) = (Si (1), Si (2), Si (3).., Si (k), P i). (6), where P i is the dependent variable representing the class name of the ith time window. The class names P i are assigned by calculating the entropy of the feature, as 17 [data] since the Entropie = Entropie (IV) belongs to the entire class.

sections.heading: C. Support Vector Machines
sections.text: SVM is a discriminatory classifier with high accuracy. Unlike DT, it prevents overfitting and can be used for online learning [18]. There are two types of classifiers in SVM: linear SVM for separable data and nonlinear SVM for non-separable data. Here, the linear classifier is used. The training characteristic and the reaction vectors can be represented as D = (P i, Si), where P i {0, 1}. The two classes are separated by the definition of a random division line H as d.Si + b = ρ, where d and b respectively represent the weight vector and the preload, while ρ represents the constant for the division of two hyperplanes. The maximum margin hyperplanes separating the points with P i = 1 from those P i = 0 are indicated as: P i = + 1 when d.Si + b > ρ (Occupied Class P i = 0, when Class Sint = 8ct) is separated by two biological planes (Evaulti Technique − Idle).

sections.heading: D. SVM with Fire Fly Algorithm
sections.text: In FFA, X is supposed to be a group of fireflies, X = [l1, l2,.. lX], which are initially at certain positions aX = [al1, al2,.. alX]. Each firefly moves and tries to find a lighter firefly that has more light intensity than its own. If a firefly, say l1, finds another lighter firefly l2 at another location that has more intensity than its own in our approach, it tends to move towards the firefly l2. The change in position is determined as [20] av + 1l1 = a v l1 + β0e − l1l2rd 2l1l2 (avl2 − a v l1) + α (edge − 0.5) (9), where the number of fly positions, the number of the Iterfly position and the number of the 1 and the 2 alalalal1, respectively, are the fire positions 1 and 1.

sections.heading: E. Linear Regression
sections.text: The flexibility of linear regression to take into account the mixture of different characteristics in different dimensions, e.g. space, frequency, time and threshold as a linear combination, is the main motivation to use it for modelling in this approach. The linear regression model for our approach is given by the following yardsticks: P i = e0 + e1S i (1) + e2S i (2) +... + ekS i (k) = e0 + k ∑ j = 1ejS i (j). (10) where the class name P i is used as a linear combination of the parameters e1, e2, ek and characteristics (Si (1), Si (2),.., Si (k)) in the ith time window. The gradual linear regression is used in this approach. In each step, the optimal term is selected based on the value of the defined "criterion." The "criterion can be expressed as the sum of the square error (SSE), the deviation of the SDRK (paragraph 11), the AIK (paragraph 11), etc.

sections.heading: F. Hidden Markov Models
sections.text: It is an unattended algorithm for modeling time series data. The motivation to use the unattended algorithm is that it does not require a training phase. In HMM, the sequence of states can be restored by analyzing the sequence of observations. The set of states and observations is represented by U = (u1, u2,... uN), G = (g1, g2,... gM), where u1 and u2 represent the states when P i = 0 and P i = 1, respectively. The observations g1 and g2 represent the value of OC i, which corresponds to each P i. HMM is defined as the sequence of probabilities, where u1 and u2 represent the states when P i = 0 and P i = 1, respectively q2. The observations g2 represent the value of OC i, which corresponds to each P i.

sections.heading: IV. NUMERICAL RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: To analyze the occupancy of the eight bands, the statistics of the data in all bands from 880 to 2500 MHz are presented in Section IV-A. The classification criteria are explained in Section IV-B. The selection of the best parameters for each model based on the classification criteria is discussed in Section IV-C. The classification models with the optimal parameters are compared to find the best classifier in relation to the CA, defined as CA = number of correct class classifiedsTotal number of test samples

sections.heading: A. Statistics of Data
sections.text: The CDF plot is shown in Fig.2, which gives the summarized view of all power ranges for the eight bands. It can be observed from Fig.2 that the eight bands can be divided into two main groups. Group A contains those bands that have large power ranges from -110 dBm to -30 dBm, including 1805-1800 MHz, 1710-1785 MHz and 2110-2170 MHz. Group B has five bands: 925-960 MHz, 2400-2500 MHz, 1900-1980 MHz and 1900-1920 MHz, which have power ranges between -110 dBm and -100 dBm. Thus, the Group A bands have larger standard deviations than the Group B bands. Next, we will discuss the effects of two main parameters (frequency and threshold) on MH1).

sections.heading: B. Classification Criteria
sections.text: This subsection examines the choice of Uoc, Loc, coni and B in section II-C as shown in Fig. 5. We used Day1 (1-1440 min), Day 2 (1441-2448 min) and Day 5 (7200-8640 min) in band 880-915 MHz, and four different values of the threshold: γ = [− 102, − 104, − 106, − 108] dBm. The parameters Uoc and Loc are selected by Ms, which represent the allocation selection that divides the data into occupied and unused classes. It varies from 0.1 to 0.9 with a step size of 0.1. It is observed in Fig. 5 that the value of CA depends on the day and the threshold value. sections.heading: C. Model Performance Comparison
sections.text: Following the discussion above, we compared the performance of the algorithms in this section with 1 month of data from band 880-915 MHz. Our tests show that the number of minimum observations / nodes for DT is 17, number of predictors for LR is 15, normal kernel for NBC, and linear kernel for SVM. The optimal splitting range, optimum threshold, and B is selected to match the data of each day.1) Supervised VS Unmonitored algorithms with k = 55: Fig. 6 (a) observes that the mean accuracy achieved by LR, SVM, NBC, and HMM is 0.9257, 0.9162, 0.8483, 0.9493, and 0.4790, respectively. Mean computing time in each iteration of LR, SVM, DT, NBC, and HMM is 350.19, 0.092, 0.0045, and 0.0171 seconds.

referenceMentions.context: Various spectrum measurement campaigns covering a wide range of frequencies have been performed [1].
For instance, the statistical and spectral occupation analysis of the measurements was presented in [2] in order to study the traffic density in all frequency bands.
In [3], autoregressive model was used to predict the radio resource availability using occupancy measurements in order to achieve uninterrupted data transmission of secondary users.

In [4], the occupancy statistics were utilized to select the best channels for control and data transmission purposes, so that less time is required for switching transmission from one channel to the other for the case when the PU appears.
Further, In [5], [6], the bandwidth efficiency was maximized by controlling the transmission power of cognitive radio using spectrum occupancy measurements.
Further, In [5], [6], the bandwidth efficiency was maximized by controlling the transmission power of cognitive radio using spectrum occupancy measurements.
In [7], different time series models were used to categorize specific occupancy patterns in the spectrum measurements.
On the other hand, machine learning (ML) is a very powerful tool that has received increasing attention recently [8].
For example, the ML works related to CR in [9][13] discussed cooperative spectrum sensing and spectrum occupancy variation.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we analyze the spectrum occupancy using different machine learning techniques. Both supervised techniques (naive Bayesian classifier (NBC), decision trees (DT), support vector machine (SVM), linear regression (LR)) and unsupervised algorithm (hidden markov model (HMM)) are studied to find the best technique with the highest classification accuracy (CA). A detailed comparison of the supervised and unsupervised algorithms in terms of the computational time and classification accuracy is performed. The classified occupancy status is further utilized to evaluate the probability of secondary user outage for the future time slots, which can be used by system designers to define spectrum allocation and spectrum sharing policies. Numerical results show that SVM is the best algorithm among all the supervised and unsupervised classifiers. Based on this, we proposed a new SVM algorithm by combining it with fire fly algorithm (FFA), which is shown to outperform all other algorithms. Index Terms Fire fly algorithm, hidden markov model, spectrum occupancy and support vector machine. March 25, 2015 DRAFT
